H0.text: Cloud is the form of water that, when present in the atmosphere, is most likely to contribute to global warming.

H1.text: Rain is the form of water that, when present in the atmosphere, is most likely to contribute to global warming.

H2.text: Vapor is the form of water that, when present in the atmosphere, is most likely to contribute to global warming.

H3.text: Snow is the form of water, when present in the atmosphere, most likely to contribute to global warming.

A4.text: Water vapor is an important greenhouse gas owing to the presence of the hydroxyl bond which strongly absorbs in the infra-red.

A5.text: Being a component of Earth's hydrosphere and hydrologic cycle, it is particularly abundant in Earth's atmosphere, where it acts as a greenhouse gas and warming feedback, contributing more to total greenhouse effect than non-condensable gases such as carbon dioxide and methane.
